items.title: I can describe how a diode behaves when forward-biased versus reverse-biased
items.what: A forward-biased diode has very low resistance and allows current to flow, while a reverse-biased diode has very high resistance and blocks current flow.
items.why: Understanding diode polarity is essential for connecting them correctly in circuits and using them to control current direction.
items.example: When a diode is connected with its banded end facing the negative terminal of the battery, it is forward-biased and current flows. Reversing the battery polarity makes it reverse-biased, blocking current.

subtopic.name: Diodes and LEDs
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how diodes and light-emitting diodes (LEDs) behave in circuits, including their non-ohmic characteristics and the relationship between current flow and polarity. You will learn to interpret I-V graphs for these semiconductor devices.
subtopic.why: Diodes and LEDs are fundamental components in modern electronics, from phone chargers to traffic lights. Understanding their one-way current behaviour allows you to design circuits that protect components, convert AC to DC, and provide efficient lighting.

items.title: I can interpret the I-V characteristic graph of a diode
items.what: The I-V graph for a diode shows almost zero current for negative voltages (reverse bias) and rapidly increasing current once the forward voltage exceeds about 0.6V for silicon diodes.
items.why: I-V characteristics reveal the non-ohmic nature of diodes and help predict circuit behaviour at different operating voltages.
items.example: On a diode I-V graph, at -50V the current is essentially zero, but at +0.6V the current begins to rise steeply, reaching perhaps 50mA at +1V.

subtopic.name: Diodes and LEDs
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how diodes and light-emitting diodes (LEDs) behave in circuits, including their non-ohmic characteristics and the relationship between current flow and polarity. You will learn to interpret I-V graphs for these semiconductor devices.
subtopic.why: Diodes and LEDs are fundamental components in modern electronics, from phone chargers to traffic lights. Understanding their one-way current behaviour allows you to design circuits that protect components, convert AC to DC, and provide efficient lighting.

items.title: I can explain how an LED differs from a standard diode
items.what: An LED emits light when current flows through it in the forward direction. Different LED colours have slightly different forward voltages, typically ranging from 1.8V to 3.5V.
items.why: LEDs are increasingly used for efficient lighting and indicator displays, making it important to understand their specific operating requirements.
items.example: A red LED has a forward voltage of about 1.8V, while a blue LED requires about 3.2V. Both emit light only when forward-biased.

subtopic.name: Diodes and LEDs
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how diodes and light-emitting diodes (LEDs) behave in circuits, including their non-ohmic characteristics and the relationship between current flow and polarity. You will learn to interpret I-V graphs for these semiconductor devices.
subtopic.why: Diodes and LEDs are fundamental components in modern electronics, from phone chargers to traffic lights. Understanding their one-way current behaviour allows you to design circuits that protect components, convert AC to DC, and provide efficient lighting.

items.title: I can interpret the I-V characteristic graph of an LED
items.what: An LED I-V graph shows zero current in reverse bias and current increasing once the forward voltage exceeds the LED's threshold voltage, which varies by colour.
items.why: The I-V characteristic helps determine the appropriate voltage and current for an LED to function properly without damage.
items.example: A green LED I-V graph shows no current until about 2V, then current rises steeply. At 20mA forward current, it might have 2.2V across it.

subtopic.name: Diodes and LEDs
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how diodes and light-emitting diodes (LEDs) behave in circuits, including their non-ohmic characteristics and the relationship between current flow and polarity. You will learn to interpret I-V graphs for these semiconductor devices.
subtopic.why: Diodes and LEDs are fundamental components in modern electronics, from phone chargers to traffic lights. Understanding their one-way current behaviour allows you to design circuits that protect components, convert AC to DC, and provide efficient lighting.

items.title: I can explain why diodes and LEDs are often connected in series with a resistor
items.what: A series resistor limits the current through the diode or LED, protecting it from excessive current that could cause overheating and damage.
items.why: Without current limiting, the low resistance of a forward-biased diode or LED would allow destructive currents to flow.
items.example: A 330Ω resistor in series with an LED connected to a 5V supply limits current to approximately (5V - 2V)/330Ω = 9mA, safely powering the LED.

subtopic.why: Diodes and LEDs are fundamental components in modern electronics, from phone chargers to traffic lights. Understanding their one-way current behaviour allows you to design circuits that protect components, convert AC to DC, and provide efficient lighting.

items.title: I can describe practical applications of diodes and LEDs
items.what: Diodes are used to convert AC to DC (rectification), protect circuits from reverse polarity, and in many electronic devices. LEDs are used for indicators, displays, and energy-efficient lighting.
items.why: Understanding applications helps connect theoretical knowledge to real-world technology you encounter daily.
items.example: A laptop charger uses diodes to convert 230V AC mains to DC. The power-on indicator is typically an LED using only milliwatts of power.

items.title: I can describe the structure and function of a potentiometer
items.what: A potentiometer consists of a long piece of high-resistance wire with a sliding contact that can select any portion of the wire, allowing continuous adjustment of resistance.
items.why: Potentiometers provide smooth, adjustable control over current or voltage in circuits, essential for dimmers and volume controls.
items.example: A volume control knob on a speaker uses a potentiometer. Rotating the knob moves the sliding contact along the resistance wire, varying the signal level.

subtopic.name: Variable Resistors and Sensors
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers potentiometers (variable resistors) and transducer sensors including light dependent resistors (LDRs) and thermistors. You will learn how these components change their resistance in response to physical conditions.
subtopic.why: These components allow circuits to respond to environmental changes like light and temperature. They form the basis of automatic control systems in everything from streetlights to refrigerators.

items.title: I can explain how a potentiometer is used as a variable resistor (rheostat)
items.what: When only two terminals of a potentiometer are connected (one end and the slider), it functions as a variable resistor that directly controls the current in a circuit.
items.why: Variable resistors allow manual adjustment of current, useful for applications like controlling motor speed or lamp brightness.
items.example: A 0-100Ω potentiometer in series with a 12V supply and a lamp can vary the current from 12V/100Ω = 0.12A (dim) to maximum when resistance is zero (bright).

subtopic.name: Variable Resistors and Sensors
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers potentiometers (variable resistors) and transducer sensors including light dependent resistors (LDRs) and thermistors. You will learn how these components change their resistance in response to physical conditions.
subtopic.why: These components allow circuits to respond to environmental changes like light and temperature. They form the basis of automatic control systems in everything from streetlights to refrigerators.

items.title: I can describe how an LDR responds to changes in light intensity
items.what: An LDR (light dependent resistor) has high resistance in darkness and low resistance in bright light. This relationship is exponential, not linear.
items.why: LDRs enable circuits to automatically respond to light levels, essential for devices like automatic night lights and camera exposure meters.
items.example: An LDR might have a resistance of 10MΩ in darkness (about 10 lux) but only 10Ω in bright sunlight (about 1000 lux).

subtopic.name: Variable Resistors and Sensors
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers potentiometers (variable resistors) and transducer sensors including light dependent resistors (LDRs) and thermistors. You will learn how these components change their resistance in response to physical conditions.
subtopic.why: These components allow circuits to respond to environmental changes like light and temperature. They form the basis of automatic control systems in everything from streetlights to refrigerators.

items.title: I can interpret a resistance versus light level graph for an LDR
items.what: The graph shows resistance decreasing exponentially as light intensity increases. Both axes are often logarithmic due to the wide range of values.
items.why: Interpreting this graph helps predict LDR behaviour at specific light levels when designing control circuits.
items.example: On a logarithmic graph, an LDR shows approximately 100Ω at 100 lux and 1000Ω at 10 lux, demonstrating the inverse relationship.

subtopic.name: Variable Resistors and Sensors
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers potentiometers (variable resistors) and transducer sensors including light dependent resistors (LDRs) and thermistors. You will learn how these components change their resistance in response to physical conditions.
subtopic.why: These components allow circuits to respond to environmental changes like light and temperature. They form the basis of automatic control systems in everything from streetlights to refrigerators.

items.title: I can describe how an NTC thermistor responds to temperature changes
items.what: An NTC (negative temperature coefficient) thermistor has high resistance when cold and low resistance when hot. This is the most common type of thermistor.
items.why: Thermistors enable temperature-sensitive circuits used in thermostats, digital thermometers, and temperature protection systems.
items.example: An NTC thermistor might have a resistance of 10,000Ω at 25°C but only 1,000Ω at 50°C.

subtopic.name: Variable Resistors and Sensors
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers potentiometers (variable resistors) and transducer sensors including light dependent resistors (LDRs) and thermistors. You will learn how these components change their resistance in response to physical conditions.
subtopic.why: These components allow circuits to respond to environmental changes like light and temperature. They form the basis of automatic control systems in everything from streetlights to refrigerators.

items.title: I can interpret a resistance versus temperature graph for a thermistor
items.what: The graph shows an exponential-like decrease in resistance as temperature increases for NTC thermistors. PTC thermistors show the opposite behaviour.
items.why: Understanding the graph allows you to select appropriate thermistors and predict their behaviour in temperature control circuits.
items.example: An NTC thermistor graph shows resistance dropping from about 30,000Ω at 0°C to about 100Ω at 100°C on a logarithmic resistance scale.

items.title: I can define what a transducer is and give examples
items.what: A transducer converts one form of energy into another. Input transducers (sensors) convert environmental energy into electrical signals; output transducers convert electrical signals into other forms.
items.why: Transducers form the interface between electronic circuits and the physical world, enabling automation and measurement.
items.example: An LDR is an input transducer (light to electrical). A buzzer is an output transducer (electrical to sound). A microphone converts sound to electrical signals.

subtopic.why: These components allow circuits to respond to environmental changes like light and temperature. They form the basis of automatic control systems in everything from streetlights to refrigerators.

items.title: I can calculate the output voltage of a potential divider
items.what: In a potential divider, the supply voltage is divided between two resistors in proportion to their resistances. The output voltage across the lower resistor is V_out = V_supply × R_lower / (R_upper + R_lower).
items.why: This calculation is fundamental for designing circuits that provide specific voltages to components or trigger electronic switches.
items.example: With a 12V supply and two equal 1kΩ resistors, V_out = 12V × 1000/(1000+1000) = 6V across the lower resistor.

subtopic.name: Potential Divider Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how potential dividers work to produce a fraction of the supply voltage, and how they can be combined with transducers like LDRs and thermistors to create automatic control circuits.
subtopic.why: Potential dividers with transducers form the sensing circuits in countless automatic systems, from streetlights that turn on at dusk to thermostats that control heating and cooling.

items.title: I can explain how a potentiometer works as a potential divider
items.what: When all three terminals of a potentiometer are connected, it acts as a potential divider. Moving the slider changes the ratio of resistances above and below it, varying the output voltage.
items.why: This configuration allows smooth adjustment of voltage output, used in dimmers and volume controls.
items.example: A 1kΩ potentiometer connected to 12V with the slider at the 3/4 position provides V_out = 12V × 0.75 = 9V at the output.

subtopic.name: Potential Divider Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how potential dividers work to produce a fraction of the supply voltage, and how they can be combined with transducers like LDRs and thermistors to create automatic control circuits.
subtopic.why: Potential dividers with transducers form the sensing circuits in countless automatic systems, from streetlights that turn on at dusk to thermostats that control heating and cooling.

items.title: I can analyse a potential divider circuit containing an LDR
items.what: In an LDR potential divider, the output voltage changes with light level. The direction of change depends on whether the LDR is in the upper or lower position of the divider.
items.why: These circuits are the basis of automatic lighting controls and light-activated alarms.
items.example: With an LDR in the lower position, as light increases, LDR resistance decreases, so V_out decreases. This could turn off a switch when daylight is detected.

subtopic.name: Potential Divider Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how potential dividers work to produce a fraction of the supply voltage, and how they can be combined with transducers like LDRs and thermistors to create automatic control circuits.
subtopic.why: Potential dividers with transducers form the sensing circuits in countless automatic systems, from streetlights that turn on at dusk to thermostats that control heating and cooling.

items.title: I can analyse a potential divider circuit containing a thermistor
items.what: In a thermistor potential divider, the output voltage changes with temperature. For an NTC thermistor, increasing temperature decreases resistance.
items.why: These circuits enable automatic temperature control in heating, cooling, and safety systems.
items.example: With an NTC thermistor in the upper position, as temperature rises, its resistance drops, so V_out increases. This could trigger a cooling fan.

subtopic.name: Potential Divider Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how potential dividers work to produce a fraction of the supply voltage, and how they can be combined with transducers like LDRs and thermistors to create automatic control circuits.
subtopic.why: Potential dividers with transducers form the sensing circuits in countless automatic systems, from streetlights that turn on at dusk to thermostats that control heating and cooling.

items.title: I can predict the behaviour of potential divider control circuits
items.what: By analysing which component is the transducer, what environmental change occurs, and where the output is taken from, you can predict whether V_out will increase or decrease.
items.why: This analysis skill allows you to design or troubleshoot sensing circuits for any application.
items.example: For a fire alarm: NTC thermistor in lower position, fire causes temperature rise, resistance drops, V_out drops. The circuit must trigger alarm when V_out falls below a threshold.

subtopic.name: Potential Divider Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how potential dividers work to produce a fraction of the supply voltage, and how they can be combined with transducers like LDRs and thermistors to create automatic control circuits.
subtopic.why: Potential dividers with transducers form the sensing circuits in countless automatic systems, from streetlights that turn on at dusk to thermostats that control heating and cooling.

items.title: I can explain how a variable resistor adjusts the switching level in a control circuit
items.what: Adding a variable resistor to one half of a potential divider allows adjustment of the threshold at which the circuit triggers, such as the light level at which a lamp turns on.
items.why: This adjustability is essential for calibrating sensors to work correctly in different environments.
items.example: In a streetlight circuit, adjusting the variable resistor changes whether the lights turn on at dusk (low light threshold) or only in complete darkness (very low threshold).

subtopic.why: Potential dividers with transducers form the sensing circuits in countless automatic systems, from streetlights that turn on at dusk to thermostats that control heating and cooling.

items.title: I can design a simple control circuit using transducers in a potential divider
items.what: A control circuit combines a transducer in a potential divider with an electronic switch. The output voltage triggers the switch when conditions meet the desired threshold.
items.why: This is the fundamental design pattern for automatic systems that respond to environmental conditions.
items.example: A nightlight circuit: LDR in upper position with fixed resistor below. In darkness, high LDR resistance causes high V_out, triggering the switch to turn on the light.

items.title: I can identify that Australian mains supply is 230V AC at 50Hz
items.what: Australian homes receive alternating current at 230 volts (with tolerance of +10% to -6%) that reverses direction 50 times per second (50 Hz).
items.why: Knowing the supply specifications is essential for selecting appropriate appliances and understanding electrical safety requirements.
items.example: An appliance rated for 120V (US standard) connected to Australian 230V supply would receive nearly double the intended voltage and likely be damaged.

subtopic.name: Household Electrical Systems
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electricity is distributed in homes, why parallel circuits are used, and how to model household AC systems as equivalent DC circuits. You will understand the basic wiring of domestic electrical installations.
subtopic.why: Understanding household electrical systems helps you use electricity safely and efficiently. Knowing why parallel circuits are used explains how appliances can be switched independently and why circuit breakers protect specific areas.

items.title: I can model an AC household circuit as an equivalent DC circuit
items.what: For analysis purposes, household AC circuits can be treated like DC circuits with active and neutral wires replacing positive and negative terminals.
items.why: This simplification allows you to apply Ohm's law and power calculations to household circuits without complex AC mathematics.
items.example: A 230V AC supply powering a 2300W heater can be analysed as a simple DC circuit: I = P/V = 2300/230 = 10A.

subtopic.name: Household Electrical Systems
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electricity is distributed in homes, why parallel circuits are used, and how to model household AC systems as equivalent DC circuits. You will understand the basic wiring of domestic electrical installations.
subtopic.why: Understanding household electrical systems helps you use electricity safely and efficiently. Knowing why parallel circuits are used explains how appliances can be switched independently and why circuit breakers protect specific areas.

items.title: I can explain why household circuits use parallel connections
items.what: Parallel circuits ensure each appliance receives the full mains voltage, can be switched independently, and continues working when other appliances fail.
items.why: Series circuits would be impractical for homes because voltage would be shared, one failure would break the whole circuit, and switching would be difficult.
items.example: In parallel, a 60W lamp and 2000W heater both receive 230V. In series, the heater would receive most of the 230V, leaving the lamp very dim.

subtopic.name: Household Electrical Systems
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electricity is distributed in homes, why parallel circuits are used, and how to model household AC systems as equivalent DC circuits. You will understand the basic wiring of domestic electrical installations.
subtopic.why: Understanding household electrical systems helps you use electricity safely and efficiently. Knowing why parallel circuits are used explains how appliances can be switched independently and why circuit breakers protect specific areas.

items.title: I can identify that switches and circuit breakers are wired in series with their loads
items.what: Switches and circuit breakers must be in series with the active wire to completely interrupt current flow to the load when opened.
items.why: Series connection ensures that when the switch opens or breaker trips, no current can flow to the appliance, making it safe.
items.example: A light switch in series with a lamp breaks the circuit when opened, stopping all current. If it were parallel, current would bypass the switch.

items.title: I can draw a circuit diagram for a simple household electrical system
items.what: A household circuit diagram shows the meter, main switch, circuit breakers, and loads (lights, power outlets) connected in parallel across active and neutral.
items.why: Reading and drawing circuit diagrams is essential for understanding electrical installations and troubleshooting problems.
items.example: A diagram shows the active wire from the meter passing through the main switch, then branching to separate circuit breakers for lighting and power circuits.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electricity is distributed in homes, why parallel circuits are used, and how to model household AC systems as equivalent DC circuits. You will understand the basic wiring of domestic electrical installations.
subtopic.why: Understanding household electrical systems helps you use electricity safely and efficiently. Knowing why parallel circuits are used explains how appliances can be switched independently and why circuit breakers protect specific areas.

items.title: I can compare power consumption in series versus parallel circuits
items.what: In parallel, each appliance operates at its rated power because each receives full voltage. In series, appliances share the voltage, reducing power consumption.
items.why: This explains why parallel wiring is essential for appliances to function correctly at their designed power levels.
items.example: Two 100W lamps in parallel consume 200W total (100W each). In series, they share 230V, each receiving 115V and consuming only 25W each (50W total).

subtopic.why: Understanding household electrical systems helps you use electricity safely and efficiently. Knowing why parallel circuits are used explains how appliances can be switched independently and why circuit breakers protect specific areas.

items.title: I can explain why the kilowatt-hour is used as a domestic unit of energy
items.what: The kilowatt-hour (kWh) is more convenient than joules for domestic use because it directly relates to appliance power ratings (in kW) and usage time (in hours).
items.why: Using kWh makes it easy to calculate energy consumption from information readily available on appliance labels and usage patterns.
items.example: A 2kW heater used for 3 hours consumes 2 × 3 = 6 kWh. In joules, this would be 6 × 3,600,000 = 21,600,000 J, which is harder to work with.

subtopic.name: Energy Calculations and Costs
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrical energy is measured in kilowatt-hours, how to calculate energy consumption from power ratings, and how to determine the cost of running electrical appliances.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy calculations helps you make informed decisions about appliance usage, compare running costs, and interpret electricity bills. These skills support both financial and environmental awareness.

items.title: I can convert between kilowatt-hours and joules
items.what: One kilowatt-hour equals 3.6 megajoules (MJ). This comes from 1 kW = 1000 J/s and 1 hour = 3600 s, so 1 kWh = 1000 × 3600 = 3,600,000 J.
items.why: Converting between units allows you to connect domestic energy usage to physics calculations using SI units.
items.example: A household using 15 kWh per day consumes 15 × 3.6 = 54 MJ of electrical energy daily.

subtopic.name: Energy Calculations and Costs
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrical energy is measured in kilowatt-hours, how to calculate energy consumption from power ratings, and how to determine the cost of running electrical appliances.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy calculations helps you make informed decisions about appliance usage, compare running costs, and interpret electricity bills. These skills support both financial and environmental awareness.

items.title: I can calculate the energy consumed by an appliance using E = Pt
items.what: Energy consumed equals power multiplied by time: E = P × t. With power in kilowatts and time in hours, the result is in kilowatt-hours.
items.why: This formula allows you to calculate energy usage for any appliance if you know its power rating and how long it operates.
items.example: A 3kW kettle used for 5 minutes (5/60 = 0.083 hours) consumes E = 3 × 0.083 = 0.25 kWh.

subtopic.name: Energy Calculations and Costs
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrical energy is measured in kilowatt-hours, how to calculate energy consumption from power ratings, and how to determine the cost of running electrical appliances.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy calculations helps you make informed decisions about appliance usage, compare running costs, and interpret electricity bills. These skills support both financial and environmental awareness.

items.title: I can calculate the current drawn by an appliance using P = VI
items.what: Current can be found by rearranging P = VI to I = P/V. For mains appliances, V = 230V.
items.why: Knowing the current drawn helps determine whether appliances can safely share a circuit with a given fuse or circuit breaker rating.
items.example: A 2300W heater draws I = 2300/230 = 10A from the mains supply.

items.title: I can calculate the cost of running an appliance
items.what: Cost equals energy consumed (in kWh) multiplied by the price per kWh. Cost = P (kW) × t (hours) × price ($/kWh).
items.why: Calculating running costs helps you make economical choices about appliance usage and understand electricity bills.
items.example: A 2kW heater used for 4 hours at $0.30/kWh costs: 2 × 4 × 0.30 = $2.40.

subtopic.name: Energy Calculations and Costs
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrical energy is measured in kilowatt-hours, how to calculate energy consumption from power ratings, and how to determine the cost of running electrical appliances.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy calculations helps you make informed decisions about appliance usage, compare running costs, and interpret electricity bills. These skills support both financial and environmental awareness.

items.title: I can interpret appliance energy ratings and compare efficiency
items.what: Energy rating labels show power consumption and star ratings. More stars indicate greater efficiency (lower running cost for the same output).
items.why: Understanding ratings helps you choose appliances that minimise energy costs and environmental impact over their lifetime.
items.example: A 5-star rated 200L refrigerator might use 200 kWh per year, while a 2-star model of the same size might use 400 kWh per year.

items.title: I can calculate standby power consumption over time
items.what: Standby power, though small (typically 0.5-5W), accumulates over hours and days. Annual standby consumption can be significant.
items.why: Standby power accounts for about 3% of household electricity use, making it worth considering when reducing energy costs.
items.example: A TV using 2W on standby for 22 hours/day: E = 0.002 × 22 × 365 = 16 kWh/year, costing about $4.80 annually at $0.30/kWh.

items.title: I can describe the effects of different levels of current on the human body
items.what: Current as low as 1mA can be felt, 10-20mA causes muscle paralysis (inability to let go), 100mA can cause heart fibrillation, and currents above 200mA are likely fatal.
items.why: Understanding these thresholds explains why even relatively low voltages can be deadly and why safety measures are essential.
items.example: At 16mA, muscles contract involuntarily, preventing a person from releasing their grip on a live wire. At 100mA for 0.5 seconds, the heart may fibrillate.

subtopic.name: Electrical Safety
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the dangers of electric shock, the operation of safety devices in household circuits (fuses, circuit breakers, RCDs), and the role of earthing in protecting people from electrical hazards.
subtopic.why: Electrical safety knowledge can save lives. Understanding how current affects the body, how safety devices work, and proper first aid procedures helps you use electricity responsibly and respond appropriately to emergencies.

items.title: I can identify the danger thresholds for current and duration
items.what: A 50mA current for more than 400ms can cause severe shock or death. Wet skin reduces resistance from about 100,000Ω to 1,000Ω, greatly increasing danger.
items.why: These thresholds explain why safety devices must act quickly and why water near electricity is particularly dangerous.
items.example: With wet hands (1000Ω resistance), touching 230V causes I = 230/1000 = 230mA, well above the lethal threshold.

subtopic.name: Electrical Safety
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the dangers of electric shock, the operation of safety devices in household circuits (fuses, circuit breakers, RCDs), and the role of earthing in protecting people from electrical hazards.
subtopic.why: Electrical safety knowledge can save lives. Understanding how current affects the body, how safety devices work, and proper first aid procedures helps you use electricity responsibly and respond appropriately to emergencies.

items.title: I can describe the first aid treatment for electric shock
items.what: First, ensure safety by disconnecting power or separating the victim using insulating material. Call 000. Check for breathing and consciousness. Perform CPR if needed.
items.why: Correct first aid response can save lives, but touching a victim still connected to electricity endangers the rescuer.
items.example: Use a wooden broom handle or dry cloth to push the victim away from the electrical source before touching them. Do not use metal or wet materials.

items.title: I can identify the function of active, neutral, and earth wires
items.what: The active (brown) wire carries the 230V supply. The neutral (blue) wire completes the circuit at close to 0V. The earth (green/yellow) wire provides a safety path to ground.
items.why: Understanding the three-wire system explains how electricity flows and how the earth wire provides protection against faults.
items.example: Current flows from active through an appliance and returns via neutral. The earth wire carries no current unless a fault occurs.

items.title: I can explain how the earth connection provides safety
items.what: The earth wire connects metal casings to the ground (0V). If a fault causes the casing to become live, current flows to earth through the low-resistance wire, tripping the safety device.
items.why: Without earthing, a fault could leave a metal casing at 230V, electrocuting anyone who touches it.
items.example: If a loose wire touches a toaster's metal case, current flows through the earth wire (not through a person), causing the circuit breaker to trip.

items.title: I can explain when and why double insulation is used instead of earthing
items.what: Double-insulated appliances have two layers of insulation between live parts and the exterior, eliminating the need for an earth connection. They have only two-pin plugs.
items.why: Double insulation is used for portable appliances where an earth connection might be impractical or where the casing is entirely plastic.
items.example: A hairdryer has no exposed metal parts and uses double insulation. Both layers of insulation would need to fail before a shock hazard exists.

items.title: I can explain how a fuse works as a safety device
items.what: A fuse contains thin wire that melts and breaks the circuit when current exceeds its rating, protecting wiring and appliances from overheating due to faults or overloading.
items.why: Fuses prevent fires and equipment damage by disconnecting the supply before excessive current causes dangerous heating.
items.example: A 10A fuse wire melts if current exceeds 10A due to a short circuit, breaking the circuit before wiring overheats.

items.title: I can explain how a circuit breaker works as a safety device
items.what: A circuit breaker uses an electromagnetic switch that trips automatically when current exceeds its rating. Unlike fuses, circuit breakers can be reset after the fault is cleared.
items.why: Circuit breakers provide the same protection as fuses but are more convenient as they do not need replacement after tripping.
items.example: A 15A circuit breaker trips when current exceeds 15A. After fixing the fault, the breaker is reset by moving the switch from off to on.

items.title: I can explain how a residual current device (RCD) provides additional protection
items.what: An RCD compares current in active and neutral wires. If they differ (indicating current leaking to earth, possibly through a person), it trips within 30 milliseconds.
items.why: RCDs protect against electrocution by detecting very small leakage currents that would not trip ordinary circuit breakers.
items.example: If 30mA leaks to earth through a person, the RCD detects the imbalance between active and neutral currents and disconnects the supply in under 30ms.
